repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Adds 2 new LSP mappings under gr prefix.

gO: vim.lsp.buf.document_symbol()

mnemonic: "s" for "symbol"

gO was planned to show document symbols

comment_data.body: would this be a good use of `gr/` or is that conceivably useful for something else (e.g. some sort of LSP-driven file navigation)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -71,12 +71,14 @@ options are not restored when the LSP client is stopped or detached.
 - |K| is mapped to |vim.lsp.buf.hover()| unless |'keywordprg'| is customized or
   a custom keymap for `K` exists.
 
-                                          *grr* *gra* *grn* *gri* *i_CTRL-S*
+                              *grr* *gra* *grn* *gri* *grs* *grS* *i_CTRL-S*
 Some keymaps are created unconditionally when Nvim starts:
 - "grn" is mapped in Normal mode to |vim.lsp.buf.rename()|
 - "gra" is mapped in Normal and Visual mode to |vim.lsp.buf.code_action()|
 - "grr" is mapped in Normal mode to |vim.lsp.buf.references()|
 - "gri" is mapped in Normal mode to |vim.lsp.buf.implementation()|
+- "grs" is mapped in Normal mode to |vim.lsp.buf.workspace_symbol()|

@@ -157,7 +157,7 @@ do
   --- client is attached. If no client is attached, or if a server does not support a capability, an
   --- error message is displayed rather than exhibiting different behavior.
   ---
-  --- See |grr|, |grn|, |gra|, |gri|, |i_CTRL-S|.
+  --- See |grr|, |grn|, |gra|, |gri|, |grs|, |grS|, |i_CTRL-S|.

comment_data.body:
> would this be a good use of `gr/` or is that conceivably useful for something else (e.g. some sort of LSP-driven file navigation)?

I think "s" for symbol will make it easier to remember, "/" is associated with searching for something. `vim.lsp.buf.list_workspace_folders` seems like it has to do with some sort of navigation, (i haven't used it though). So maybe reserve `/` for that?

@@ -71,12 +71,14 @@ options are not restored when the LSP client is stopped or detached.

comment_data.body:
>  "/" is associated with searching for something.

So we should reserve `gr/` for builtin (or delegated) "freceny"/fuzzy-finder (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/660).

comment_data.body:
The `*gO*` tag should be removed here. Keep the gO mention  below, but also mention the LSP default at the existing `*gO*` tag.

And then check that CI passes, and fixe any problems if not.

comment_data.body:
Sorry, I'll make sure to up my communication for the next time. 

I only have access to a phone for the next few days, but it's easier for me to make sure the PR is ready for review when I have access to my computer 

I will let you know when I do (I know its just 1 line change, but there could be some other problem I might not notice, so I don't want to waste your time)

comment_data.body:
hey, can you please elaborate what you mean by:

> but also mention the LSP default at the existing *gO* tag.

Wouldn't this line already do that:

```
 "gO" is mapped in Normal mode to |vim.lsp.buf.document_symbol()|
```

2. I removed the `*gO*` tag
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -71,12 +71,14 @@ options are not restored when the LSP client is stopped or detached.
 - |K| is mapped to |vim.lsp.buf.hover()| unless |'keywordprg'| is customized or
   a custom keymap for `K` exists.
 
-                                          *grr* *gra* *grn* *gri* *i_CTRL-S*
+                                 *grr* *gra* *grn* *gri* *gO* *i_CTRL-S*

comment_data.body:
I'm confused why removing the tag was necessary though..

 in `_defaults.lua` we also have this line

```
 --- See |grr|, |grn|, |gra|, |gri|, |gO|, |i_CTRL-S|.
```
i'll also remove the mention of `gO` from there if it makes sense, but I don't really understand why it should be removed because other mappings like `grr` and `gra` do have their tags in that list e.g. `*grr*`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -71,12 +71,14 @@ options are not restored when the LSP client is stopped or detached.
 - |K| is mapped to |vim.lsp.buf.hover()| unless |'keywordprg'| is customized or
   a custom keymap for `K` exists.
 
-                                          *grr* *gra* *grn* *gri* *i_CTRL-S*
+                                 *grr* *gra* *grn* *gri* *gO* *i_CTRL-S*

@@ -71,12 +71,13 @@ options are not restored when the LSP client is stopped or detached.
 - |K| is mapped to |vim.lsp.buf.hover()| unless |'keywordprg'| is customized or
   a custom keymap for `K` exists.
 
-                                          *grr* *gra* *grn* *gri* *i_CTRL-S*
+                                   *grr* *gra* *grn* *gri* *i_CTRL-S*

comment_regular_data.body:
Imo the other way around would make more sense
since workspace is a bigger scope than document

> Imo the other way around would make more sense since workspace is a bigger scope than document

Ok, so I was previously of the opinion that the one with less keystrokes should be the one that is lowercase. but really, i think it makes more sense to go in the direction of -- lower scope, so lowercase letter. i agree with you

> `gO` should show current document symbols, that was always the plan for `gO`.

Ok, that makes sense actually. I have changed it so that `grs` is workspace symbols, `gO` is document symbols
workspace symbol search has overlap with `:tjump`. Given that you typically use it with a query I'm not sure if a dedicated keymap is warranted?

> workspace symbol search has overlap with `:tjump`. Given that you typically use it with a query I'm not sure if a dedicated keymap is warranted?

I still feel like having a keymap for it would be useful due to how common this action is used.

I didn't find anything for `:h grs` so I don't understand how it overlaps. If it does and I am missing something, then we maybe can use `grS`?

Sorry I phrased that poorly. What I meant to say is that `:tselect`/`:tjump` also use workspace symbols (via the lsp tagfunc) and typing `:ts <query>` has about the same number of keystrokes as would typing `grs <query>` has.

The UI is currently different, but I think we should improve that instead of offering more ways to do the same thing.

(and `vim.lsp.buf.workspace_symbol` currently doesn't work well for many clients - each is overriding the previous' results, while the tagfunc already handles that correct)
so let's move forward with gO but drop the other one for now.
Ok, so I can see where you are coming from. I've removed grs

I'm not particularly sure that the current status of `vim.lsp.buf.document_symbols` is sufficient to be the default; I've at least found two potential issues with it.

1. `gO` is used in `help` and `:Man` to display the outline, which is the meaning of `O`. However, our current `vim.lsp.buf.document_symbols` ignores the hierarchy and directly returns all symbols. Ideally, it should only return the first or second level of scope.
2. Even if we use it in a way that maps to `vim.lsp.buf.references`, achieving something similar to `grr` but displaying all symbols, there are still shortcomings. This is because the current implementation still ignores the scope of the symbols. An improvement has been made for `vim.lsp.buf.references` have not been made for this yet, I've created https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30860.

I think its best to find solutions to the above two issues before promoting it to the default mapping.

> `gO` is used in `help` and `:Man` to display the outline, which is the meaning of `O`. However, our current `vim.lsp.buf.document_symbols` ignores the hierarchy and directly returns all symbols. Ideally, it should only return the first or second level of scope.

It could be improved, but I don't see why that would block this. We have `document_symbols` which does something useful, and is the current best approximation of a "document outline". We can always update the mapping if we get something better in the future.
I will update the docs for `:help gO` in another PR.

title: feat(defaults): map gO to document symbol
